Department of Mathematical and Statistical Sciences
Marquette University" # date: "January 02 2025" format: revealjs: html-math-method: katex highlight-style: github code-block-bg: true self-contained: false slide-number: c/t incremental: false width: 1800 height: 1000 margin: 0.05 logo: "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e8/Marquette_Golden_Eagles_logo.svg" footer: "[mssc6250-s25.github.io/website](https://mssc6250-s25.github.io/website/)" theme: ["simple", "styles.scss"] echo: false multiplex: true code-link: true transition: none ## fade slide convex concave zoom title-slide-attributes: data-background-color: "#447099" # data-background-image: images/paper-texture.jpg # data-background-size: cover # data-background-color: "#698ED5" editor: source execute: freeze: auto echo: false --- # {visibility="hidden"} \def\bx{\mathbf{x}} \def\bg{\mathbf{g}} \def\bw{\mathbf{w}} \def\bbeta{\boldsymbol \beta} \def\bX{\mathbf{X}} \def\by{\mathbf{y}} \def\bH{\mathbf{H}} \def\bI{\mathbf{I}} \def\bS{\mathbf{S}} \def\bW{\mathbf{W}} \def\T{\text{T}} \def\cov{\mathrm{Cov}} \def\cor{\mathrm{Corr}} \def\var{\mathrm{Var}} \def\E{\mathrm{E}} \def\bmu{\boldsymbol \mu} \DeclareMathOperator*{\argmin}{arg\,min} \def\Trace{\text{Trace}} # Taipei, Taiwan {background-image="images/01-syllabus/taiwan.jpeg" background-size="cover" background-position="50% 50%" background-color="#447099"} ::: {.absolute bottom="50" right="10"} ![](images/01-syllabus/taiwan.svg){width="500" fig-alt="Taiwan location"} ::: ::: notes - Hello everyone, how are you? I hope you have a great winter break. Welcome to 6250 Statistical Machine Learning course. I am your instructor Cheng-Han Yu. - First thing first. Get to know each other. Let me first introduce my self. I was born and grew up in Taipei, Taiwan, my home country, which is a island right next to China. Taipei is a big city in terms of population. It is about the same population size as Chicago. This building is called Taipei 101, which is the tallest building in Taiwan. ::: ## My Journey {background-image="images/01-syllabus/sample_gate.png" background-size="cover" background-position="50% 50%" background-opacity="0.3"} - Assistant Professor (2020/08 - ) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/mu.svg){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - Postdoctoral Fellow ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/rice.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - PhD in Statistics and Applied Mathematics ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/ucsc.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - MA in Economics/PhD program in Statistics ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/iub.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: ::: notes After college, working and doing military service for several years, I came to the US for my PhD degree. Originally I would like to study economics, but then I switched my major to statistics. - I got my master degree in economics from Indiana University Bloomington, then I transferred to UC Santa Cruz to finish my PhD studies. - Then I spent two years doing my postdoctoral research at Rice University in Houston, Texas. - Finally, in fall 2020, I came to Marquette as an assistant professor. - Midwest/Indiana-West/California-South/Texas-Midwest/Wisconsin - Been to any one of these universities/cities? - The most beautiful campus. - Who are international students? I can totally understand how hard studying and living in another country. Feel free to share your stories or difficulties, and I am more than happy to help you if you have any questions. - Poor listening and speaking skills. I was shy. - OK so, this is my background. How about you introducing yourself as well. You can share anything, your major, hobbies, your favorite food, what do you want to do after graduation, anything, - I have the class list. I'd like to learn your face and remember your name. You know, you all wear a mask. It's hard to recognize you and connect your name and your face. - When I call your name, you can say something about yourself. No need to be long, couple of seconds are good. ::: ## My Research - Bayesian spatio-temporal modeling and machine learning algorithms in neuroimaging - Bayesian deep learning for image classification - Efficient MCMC for high dimensional regression - Data science education ::: columns ::: column **fMRI** ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/activate.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: column **EEG** ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/eeg.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## How to Reach Me - Office hours **TuTh 4:50 - 5:50 PM** and **Wed 12 - 1 PM** in **Cudahy Hall 353**. - 📧 + Answer your question within 24 hours. + Expect a reply on **Monday** if shoot me a message **on weekends**. + Start your subject line with **[mssc6250]** followed by a **clear description of your question**. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/email6250.png){fig-align='center' width=45%} ::: ::: + I will **NOT** reply your e-mail if ... **Check the email policy in the [syllabus](https://mssc6250-s25.github.io/website/course-syllabus.html)**! ## Prerequisites - On bulletin: MATH 4720 (Intro to Statistics), MATH 3100 (Linear Algebra) and/or MSSC 5780 (Regression Analysis) - Programming experience (Who does machine learning without coding?) . . . - Having taken MSSC 5700 (Probability) and MSSC 5710 (Stats Inference) or other math and statistics courses (Stats Computing, etc) is recommended. ## Textbook ::: columns ::: column - [(**ISL**) *An Introduction to Statistical Learning*](https://www.statlearning.com/), by James et al. Publisher: Springer. - Discuss all chapters except Chapter 11 (survival analysis) and 13 (multiple testing). - R and Python code In the Preface, > *... for advanced undergraduates or master's students in Statistics or related quantitative fields,* > *... concentrate more on the applications of the methods and less on the mathematical details.* ::: ::: column ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/isl.png){fig-align='center' width=65%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Optional References {visibility="hidden"} ::: columns ::: column - [(**HML**) *Hands-On Machine Learning with R*](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/), by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. Publisher: CRC Press. - Focus on R implementation ::: ::: column ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/hmlr.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Optional References ::: columns ::: column - [(**MML**) *Mathematics for Machine Learning*](https://mml-book.github.io/), by Marc Peter Deisenroth, A. Aldo Faisal, and Cheng Soon Ong. Publisher: Cambridge University Press. - Focus on the mathematical concepts behind the models ::: ::: column ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/mml.png){fig-align='center' width=69%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Optional References ::: columns ::: column - [(**PMLI**) *Probabilistic Machine Learning: An Introduction*](https://probml.github.io/pml-book/book1.html), by Kevin Murphy. Publisher: MIT Press. - Self-contained with lots of mathematics foundations - Python code ::: ::: column ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/pmli.png){fig-align='center' width=85%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Optional References ::: columns ::: column - [(**PMLA**) *Probabilistic Machine Learning: Advanced Topics*](https://probml.github.io/pml-book/book2.html), by Kevin Murphy. Publisher: MIT Press. - PhD level - Probabilistic or distributional-based ::: ::: column ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/pmla.png){fig-align='center' width=85%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Optional References ::: columns ::: column - [(**ESL**) *The Elements of Statistical Learning, 2nd edition*](https://hastie.su.domains/ElemStatLearn/), by Hastie et. al. Publisher: Springer. - For PhD students or researchers in mathematical sciences - Frequentist-based ::: ::: column ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/esl.png){fig-align='center' width=65%} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Course Website - ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/website_s25.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ## Learning Management System ([D2L](https://d2l.mu.edu/d2l/home/589421)) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/d2l_s25.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: - **News** - Submit your homework **Assessments > Dropbox**. - Check your grade **Assessments > Grades**. ## Grading Policy ✨ - The grade is earned out of **1000 total points** distributed as follows: - **Homework: 500 pts** - **Midterm mini-project presentations: 300 pts** - **Final project: 200 pts** - ❌ No extra credit projects/homework/exam to compensate for a poor grade. ## Grade-Percentage Conversion - Your final grade is based on your percentage of pts earned out of 1000 pts. - $[x, y)$ means greater than or equal to $x$ and less than $y$. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Grade Percentage
A [94, 100]
A- [90, 94)
B+ [87, 90)
B [83, 87)
B- [80, 83)
C+ [77, 80)

````` ::: ::: ## Homework (500 pts) - **Assessments > Dropbox** and upload your homework in **PDF** format. - ❌ **No make-up homework**. - Due **Friday 11:59 PM ** (**Hard deadline and no late submission**). - You have **at least one week** to finish your homework. ## Mini-Project Presentation (300 pts) - There will be 2 in-class mini-project presentations (150 pts each). - Learn from each other by presenting and discussing the assigned topics. - More details about the activity will be released later. ## Final Project (200 pts) - The final project is submitted as a paper (and some relevant work?) - The project submission deadline is [**Thursday, 5/8, 10 AM**]{.red}. - More details about the project will be released later. ## Which Programming Language? ::: columns ::: {.column width="25%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c3/Python-logo-notext.svg){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="25%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://www.r-project.org/logo/Rlogo.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="25%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/21/Matlab_Logo.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="25%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1f/Julia_Programming_Language_Logo.svg){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: [Use any language you prefer!]{.r-fit-text .fragment style="color: #EE6331;"} ## Generative AI and Sharing/Reusing Code Policy ::: columns ::: {.column width="75%"} - You are responsible for the content of all work submitted for this course. - You may use generative AI tools such as ChatGPT or DALL-E to generate a first draft of text for your assignments, provided that this use is [appropriately documented and cited]{.underline}. - Learn how to cite the use of AI in [MLA](https://style.mla.org/citing-generative-ai/) and [APA](https://apastyle.apa.org/blog/how-to-cite-chatgpt) format, and [more](https://libguides.marquette.edu/generative_technologies/citing) ::: ::: {.column width="25%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/genai.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: . . . ### Sharing/Reusing Code - Unless explicitly stated otherwise, you may make use of any online resources, but you must **explicitly cite** where you obtained any code you directly use or use as inspiration in your solutions. - Any recycled code that is discovered and is not explicitly cited will be treated as plagiarism, regardless of source.

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
